Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Automatic Document and Record Disposition and Retention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Record and document retention (document disposition) has become a serious problem for both organizations and individuals since most documents now created are digital. Digital documents offer both problems and advantages. Digital documents are easily versioned, copied and disseminated. Thus, there can be several similar copies or versions of important or relevant documents in many locations. Document or record disposition can be applied to or is needed by individuals, organizations and domains (such as law, science, policy, etc.) for effective information management over long periods of time. This problem is of epic proportions and is becoming a major problem in organizations and for individuals throughout the world where effective record disposition is either required by law or by the organization or by practical limitations in systems.

This exploratory project investigates possible automatic document disposition methods based on algorithms for text inspection, mining, and search. The challenges lie in finding scalable, adaptable algorithms that can be used in several if not all application domains. In addition, variability in users presents many problems. A disposition method or procedure may vary depending on the user, organization and domain (e.g., law, health records, etc.). The approach explored in this project applies and extends machine learning methods to these problems since these methods adapt to variability in data, areas and domains. Using such approaches, automated disposition methods can be readily applied to these different areas such as science, email and legal records. This research lays the groundwork for adaptive methods for a variety of domains in terms of applicability, performance and scalability. this proof-of-concept project initially focuses on the Enron email data set that is publicly available and is be used to demonstrate the feasibility of the approach since email can be considered a special case of document disposition. If successful, other disposition domains such as science and government data will be explored. This work will show the viability of developing and applying machine learning methods to an important and diverse problem domain.

The results from this exploratory project together with insights gathered from methods used in large scale document search are expected to yield understanding as to how we can better manage our digital past and the rapidly expanding digital future. The results are expected to introduce this important problem to other researchers and document disposition professionals and lead to collaborations with industry. Data and research results will be made available through a publicly available website (http://clgiles.ist.psu.edu/disposeseer/) and research papers will be published and presented in appropriate venues. The project provides research experience for graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in several outcomes related to document disposition. The first is a general approach to performing document disposition, based on similarity search. The idea is that similarity search provides an efficient and scalable method for identifying documents in a collection that are candidates for disposition.

The use of similarity search addresses two main challenges. The first challenge relates to scalability and is addressed by making use of state of the art scalable methods in information retrieval. The second challenge relates to the availability of labelled data for classification and is addressed since, given only a few data samples, similarity search can effectively retrieve similar files without requiring the same amount of data required to train a supervised classifier.

Using these methods, a generic similar document search engine, SimSeerX, has been developed and made publicly available. The general applicability of the search engine has been shown through its use with several datasets, including Wikipedia, plagiarized documents, academic documents and new articles. SimSeerX has also been used as part of a project to automatically create text books.

Another significant outcome has been the development of state of the art methods for retrieving candidate sources of plagiarism from the Web. These methods are based on automatically extracting queries from suspicious documents and querying a public Web search engine. The search results returned by the search engine are then classified as potential sources of plagiarism using information available at query time and without actually retrieving the documents. These methods have shown to be highly effective, achieving the best performance in CLEF Conference PAN plagiarism detection competitions in 2013, 2014 and 2015 and have also been shown to be highly scalable since they have been used at Web scale.

The project also investigated the use of similarity search and social network information for aiding in email classification. Using the Enron email dataset, it was shown how similarity search can be used to supplement a dataset with additional data and how features characterizing the behavior of individuals in a social network are useful for email classification. It is expected that the use of similarity search for identifying training data is a useful technique for document classification in general and that the integration of social network information can be considered a special case of document classification given networked information. Other types of networks that could be useful include Web hyperlink networks for webpages and citation networks and co-authorship networks for academic documents.

The project also produced a Web service, CiteSeerExtractor, for information extraction from scholarly documents. The Web service provides a wrapper around the information extractors in CiteSeerX and can easily be integrated into document workflows.

Lastly, the project resulted in several conference publications and websites and funding for a graduate student to gain useful research experience in machine learning, information retrieval and systems design. Services were created for use by the public: SimSeerX and EnronSeer and code has been made available via GitHub.
